poem:
"Once More in the Half-Light of Blackpool"

Come all to the coast, where the spotlight hath dimmed
On saucy tales cloaked in shadows, faces grinned.
Rebirth in the nightglow, seasoned with cheer,
Blackpool, thy light, shrouds not in mockery, but veneer.
Gentle jest of a town that winks in the dark,
Your neon mirth paints our love, bold and stark.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘It’s about restoring pride’: can Blackpool use its saucy image to win back the crowds? Risque jokes have long been a feature of stage shows in Blackpool, Britain’s cheeky home of seaside fun. Traditionally, quite a few of these are told at the expense of the town, known for its autumn illuminations, with gentler gags noting how much better it looks in the dark. Now the London opening of Jez Butterworth’s latest play, The Hills". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
